mNFSQx-y6.memHandModelNotes: NatureServe global range comments for G. s. fuscus subspecies identify elevation minimum as 3300 feet. No elevation limits mentioned for G. s. coloratus subspecies. Menzel (2003) uses an elevation minimum of 1036 meters for a habitat model in WV. Ford et al. (2004) state "restricted to high elevation (typically >900 m)" forests in the Allegheny Mountains of VA and WV. Both Menzel and Ford (2003, 2004) are concerned solely with the G. s. fuscus subspecies. I altered the range for this species (see Range Notes) and changed the elevation minimum from 1371 m to 1035 m. MJR 28 March 2008.

habitat_description:
Western Glaucomys sabrinus inhabit montane and subalpine forests of Engelmann spruce, sitka spruce, white fir, red fir, subalpine fir, Douglas-fir, western hemlock, redcedar, lodgepole pine, sugar pine, and/or incense cedar (McKeever, 1960; Musser, 1961; Andersen et al., 1980; Halvorson, 1982; Doyle, 1990; Carey et al., 1992; Witt, 1992; Waters and Zabel, 1995; Ransome and Sullivan, 1997; Carey, 2000; Smith and Nichols, 2003; Lehmkuhl et al., 2006; Meyer et al., 2007; Smith, 2007; Wilson et al., 2008; Smith, 2009). The species is occasionally found in drier sites with ponderosa pine or Jeffrey pine (McKeever, 1960; Halvorson, 1982; Waters and Zabel, 1995; Lehmkuhl et al., 2006; Smith, 2007; Gabel et al., 2010) and/or aspen (Rogers et al., 2000; Gabel et al., 2010).

Eastern populations are similarly found in spruce and spruce-fir forests (Payne et al., 1989; Reynolds et al., 1999; Cote and Ferron, 2001; Hackett and Pagels, 2003; Menzel, 2003; Ford et al., 2004; Menzel et al., 2006; Ford et al., 2007; Holloway and Malcolm, 2007) and in forests of eastern hemlock and white pine (Connor, 1960). According to Holloway and Malcolm (2007), “Spruce appears to be a key habitat characteristic in eastern populations, as this feature is consistently a strong predictor of northern flying squirrel presence”. Eastern populations are also associated with mixed forests that contain a northern hardwood component of sugar maple, yellow birch, paper birch, American beech, black cherry, and red maple (Connor, 1960; Payne et al., 1989; Hackett and Pagels, 2003; Menzel, 2003; Menzel et al., 2006; Ford et al., 2007).

The species nests in tree cavities and external nests on red spruce and Norway spruce (Ford et al., 2007), northern hardwood species (Weigl and Osgood, 1974; Menzel, 2003; Menzel et al., 2006), as well as red fir, douglas-fir, white fir, sugar pine, and ponderosa pine (Wilson et al., 2008)

Some studies show G. sabrinus occupancy and/or abundance to be associated with canopy cover (Hackett and Pagels, 2003; Meyer et al., 2007), while others reveal no statistically significant impact of canopy cover (Gabel et al., 2010). Nevertheless, the species has not been documented in open woodlands or savannas.

Understory composition has been shown relevant to the occurrence of northern flying squirrel, with ericaceous shrubs (Carey, 1995) and ferns (Hackett and Pagels, 2003) indicating suitable habitat. Sapling density has also been positively correlated with species presence (Holloway and Malcolm, 2007). Payne et al. (1989) found no understory factors to be pertinent.

The species avoids sites where northern red oak (Q. rubra) is present (Ford et al., 2004) as well as stands of pure cottonwood or aspen (Musser, 1961), monoculture (Smith, 2009), and meadows (Smith, 2009).

In the western U.S., G. sabrinus is found from elevations near sea level along the Pacific coast (Smith and Nichols, 2003; Smith, 2007) to 3353 m in Utah (Musser, 1961; Weigl, 1978). The lower elevation limit in the southwest is roughly 914 m (Weigl, 1978). In the southeastern U.S., elevation constraints are from ~1000 m to ~1650 m (Payne et al., 1989; Menzel, 2003; Menzel et al., 2006; Ford et al., 2007). In the northeast, the species found from as low as 300 m (Weigl and Osgood, 1974; Weigl, 1978) in Pennsylvania and New York and from near sea-level in New Brunswick (Vernes, 2004) to more than 1600 m (Gordeon, 1962).
